S1.T1.caption: Table 1. Existing surveys on FL-related topics and our new contributions.
S1.T1.table:
Paper Key topic Recent Advances in FL Taxonomy Highlights
Resource management Security and privacy Incentive mechanism Personalized FL
(9, ) FL concept ✗ ✗ ✗ ✗ None A discussion of the architectures, algorithms, and data processing methods in FL systems.
(10, ) FL concept ✓ ✓ ✗ ✗ None A survey of the FL concepts, technologies and associated learning approaches.
(11, ) Security and privacy in FL ✗ ✓ ✗ ✗ None A review on the security and privacy issues in FL systems.
(16, ) FL in edge networks ✓ ✗ ✓ ✗ None A survey on the integration of FL in mobile edge networks.
(12, ) FL for IoT ✓ ✓ ✓ ✗ None A survey on the use of FL in IoT networks.
(13, ) FL for IIoT ✓ ✓ ✗ ✗ The discussion of FL in healthcare is very limited. A survey on the combination of FL and IIoT, mostly focusing on technical issues in FL implementation.
(14, ) FL for health informatics ✗ ✗ ✗ ✗ The discussion of FL in healthcare is very limited. A study on the FL architectures and models, with a very short introduction to healthcare.
(15, ) FL for digital health ✗ ✗ ✗ ✗ The discussion of FL in healthcare is very limited. A discussion of technical issues and requirements of FL in digital health.
Our work FL for smart healthcare ✓ ✓ ✓ ✓ A holistic taxonomy is presented. A comprehensive survey on the use of FL in smart healthcare, from motivations, requirements to FL designs and applications in a wide range of healthcare domains.
references: Driven by the recent advances of FL, many studies have been conducted to survey its related topics, including healthcare. For example, the works in (9, ) and (10, ) present the key FL concept and its enabling protocols and technical challenges in FL design and implementation. The survey in (11, ) discusses the security and privacy issues in FL systems, and described possible solutions for evaluations of malicious threats in FL networks. The integration of FL in mobile edge networks is investigated in (16, ), where challenges in FL implementation are explored, such as communication costs, resource allocation, and privacy and security. Meanwhile, the convergence of FL and Internet-of-Things (IoT) is explored in (12, ), by providing a survey on the technical issues in FL designs, such as sparsification, robustness, privacy, and scalability, along with a brief discussion of FL applications in IoT. Moreover, the authors in (13, ) present an overview of the FL applications in industrial IoT, where the focus is on the discussion of characteristics and fundamentals of FL, while the discussion of FL usage in healthcare is limited. The work in (14, ) mainly discusses the FL architectures and models with a very brief introduction to the roles of FL in healthcare informatics. Another study in (15, ) mostly considers technical issues and requirements of using FL in future digital health. However, the latest advances in FL such as resource-aware FL, secure and privacy-enhanced FL, incentive-aware FL, and personalized FL have not been fully explored. The comparison of the related works and our paper is summarized in Table 1.

S4.T2.caption: Table 2. Summary of recent advances in FL designs for smart healthcare.
S4.T2.table:
Theme Ref. FL type FL clients FL aggregator Key contributions Limitations / Potential directions
Resource Allocation (yang2020scheduling, ) HFL IoMT devices Cloud server Impact of scheduling policies on the convergence rate. Only three base scheduling policies are considered.
(nguyen2020toward, ) HFL Smart devices Edge server A resource allocation for multiple FL services. The proposed algorithms are not evaluated on the health dataset.
(xu2021bandwidth, ) HFL Smart devices Edge server Each device runs only one FL service and bandwidth allocation schemes for intra- and inter-service is proposed. The proposed algorithms are not evaluated on the health dataset.
Secure FL (li2021blockchain, ) HFL /VFL Smart devices Serverless Bockchain for decentralized FL updates and the impact of lazy nodes are studied. Blockchain may increase the computing requirements of smart devices.
(bonawitz2016practical, ) General FL FL users Aggregation server A seminal approach of secure aggregation for FL. The proposed method is examined on the non-health dataset.
(so2021turbo, ) General FL FL users Aggregation server An efficient secure aggregation method namely Turbo-Aggregate. Only numerical results are reported.
references: We summarize this section in the taxonomy Table 2 and Table 3 along with the key technical aspects of each reference work to provide more insights into the recently advanced FL designs for smart healthcare.

S4.T3.caption: Table 3. Summary of recent advances in FL designs for smart healthcare (continued).
S4.T3.table:
Theme Ref. FL type FL clients FL aggregator Key contributions Limitations / Potential directions
Privacy- enhanced FL (wu2021incentivizing, ) HFL IoMT devices Cloud server A privacy-preserving FL approach with multi-dimensional cost. The propose approach is evaluated via numerical simulations.
(malekzadeh2021dopamine, ) HFL hospitals Cloud server A method is proposed to balance the differential privacy guarantee and deep learning accuracy. Advanced encryption is needed for privacy enhancement.
(38, ) HFL Smart phones FL server A study on the tradeoff between privacy protection and training accuracy. The convergence of FL algorithms has not been verified.
(kerkouche2021privacy, ) HFL Hospital Central server A privacy-preserving resource allocation, namely FL-SIGN-DP, is developed. AI techniques such as DRL can be adopted at the server to exploit the historical samples.
Incentive- aware FL (sarikaya2019motivating, ) HFL IoMT devices FL server A Stackelberg game is proposed to stimulate the participant of IoMT devices. Results are reported using numerical results only.
(tangincentive, ) Cross-silo FL Hospitals Data centre A non-cooperative game approach is used to devise an incentive mechanism for resource allocation. The model is developed based on the assumption of IID data among hospitals.
(zhao2021efficient, ) HFL Smart device FL server A DRL-based approach to evaluate the contribution of data owners. A reward model can be developed to encourage the participant of more FL users.
Personalized FL (45, ) HFL In-home sensing devices Cloud server A edge-cloud FL architecture is proposed for in-home healthcare services. The convergence of the proposed FL algorithm has not been reported.
(gudur2020resource, ) HFL IoMT devices FL server An α𝛼\alpha-weighted update is proposed to mitigate the effect of label heterogeneity. The convergence of FL algorithms has not been verified.
(rudovic2021personalized, ) HFL Smart devices FL server A personalized FL approach is developed to predict the pain via face images. The challenge caused by data imbalance should be further investigated.
references: We summarize this section in the taxonomy Table 2 and Table 3 along with the key technical aspects of each reference work to provide more insights into the recently advanced FL designs for smart healthcare.

S5.T4.caption: Table 4. Taxonomy of FL applications for smart healthcare.
S5.T4.table:
Applied domain Ref. FL type FL clients FL aggregator Key contributions Limitations
EHRs Management (35, ) HFL Hospitals Cloud server A collaborative learning with FL for EHRs processing. Convergence of the FL algorithm has not been verified.
(36, ) HFL Smart phones Data server An FL scheme for predicting hospitalizations of patients. The proposed model is simple and lacks detailed evaluations.
(38, ) HFL Hospitals Data server An differential privacy-based FL for federated EHRs training. The feasibility of differential privacy in real-world FL implementations should be considered.
(40, ) HFL Radiology client center Cloud server An FL-based scheme with split learning for EHRs training. The proposed model is simple and training complexity is not verified.
(42, ) HFL Hospitals Data server Uncertainty FL for preterm-birth-related data analytics. The complexity of local training at each hospital should be analyzed.
Health Monitoring (45, ) VFL Smart phones Cloud server A personalized FL scheme for remote activity recognition monitoring. Secure aggregation in FL communications has not considered.
(46, ) FTL Wearable devices Cloud server A personalized FL scheme with transfer learning for human activity recognition. Communication costs and training complexity have not been verified.
(47, ) HFL Hospitals Cloud server A two-stage federated natural language processing approach for obesity analytics. The privacy preservation for FL training should be considered.
(48, ) VFL Mobile devices Cloud server An FL-based mobile activity monitoring approach for supporting healthcare applications. The comparison with other non-IID-aware FL techniques has been ignored.
(49, ) HFL Medical sites Data centre An FL-based approach for large nationwide health insurance data analytics in the US. Issues related to federation agreement among medical sites need to be clarified in real-world settings.
(50, ) HFL Mobile devices Data centre An FL-based method to predict mood using mobile devices. The training resource usage and privacy should be considered in mobile FL.
references: In summary, we list the emerging applications of FL in smart healthcare in the taxonomy Table 4 and Table 5 along with the key technical aspects of each reference work to provide more insights into the integrated FL-healthcare use cases.

S5.T5.caption: Table 5. Taxonomy of FL applications for smart healthcare (continued).
S5.T5.table:
Applied domain Ref. FL type FL clients FL aggregator Key contributions Limitations
Medical Imaging (53, ) VFL Hospitals Cloud server A variation-aware FL scheme for medical image construction. Learning accuracy has not been investigated.
(54, ) HFL MRI scan machines Federated server A privacy-enhanced FL scheme for brain imaging. FL convergence has not been investigated.
(55, ) HFL Medical sites Data centre An FL-based MRI analytic framework for brain imaging. The practical aspects of the federated MRI training should be taken.
(58, ) HFL Hospitals Data centre An FL scheme for supporting diagnosis of acute neurological symptoms. The proposed model is too simple and more simulations need to be done.
(59, ) HFL Hospitals Data centre An FL-based medical imaging approach with differential privacy for collaborative secure training. Comparison of DL techniques in FL simulation has not been performed.
COVID-19 Detection (68, ) HFL Hospitals Data centre An FL scheme for collaborative COVID-19 detection. The proposed model is simple with a lack of detailed analysis.
(69, ) HFL Hospitals Data centre A number of experiments for COVID-19 detection with FL. The convergence of FL algorithms has not been verified.
(70, ) HFL Data clients Data centre A dynamic fusion-based FL method for CT scan image analysis to diagnose COVID-19 infections. Learning efficiency, e.g., latency, has not been verified.
(71, ) HFL Medical institutions Data centre An FL-based solution for COVID-19 screening from Chest X-ray images. Data loss caused by FL communications has not been considered.
(74, ) VFL Hospitals Aggregator A federated deep learning method for detecting COVID-19 lung abnormalities in CT. Training latency has not been analyzed.
(73, ) VFL Medical institutions Cloud server An FL method for COVID region segmentation in chest CT using multi-national data from China, Italy, Japan. Theorical analysis of FL communications and convergence should be provided.
references: In summary, we list the emerging applications of FL in smart healthcare in the taxonomy Table 4 and Table 5 along with the key technical aspects of each reference work to provide more insights into the integrated FL-healthcare use cases.
